name: being, becoming friends and getting to know someone

children.name: know b1
children.definition: know if you know sb, you have met them before, can remember their face or name, and know sth about them, such as where they live, what their job is etc: quen biết
examples: do you two know each other?
everyone who knew her described her as a kind, generous person.
do you know anyone who can repair a boiler?
although we worked for him for years, cathy was the only one who knew him well.

children.name: know sb by sight x
children.definition: know sb by sight to be able to recognize sb but not know their name or anything else about them: biết mặt
examples: bentson knew all the women by sight, but he’d never exchanged more than a few words with any of them.
two or three of the salespeople knew me by sight.

children.name: be acquainted with x
children.definition: be acquainted with  to know sb because you have met once or twice before but to not know much about them:
examples: ‘have you met lee davidson?’ ‘no, i don’t think we’re acquainted.’
he lived in great russell street and became acquainted with keynes and other famous british thinkers of the time.

children.name: help sb get to know each other
introduce b1
children.definition: introduce if youintroducesb to a person they have never met before, you tell them each other’s names: giới thiệu
examples: have you two been introduced?
yes, we were introduced last year at your party.
introduce sb to sth
that’s a friend of mine from college. do you want me to introduce you to him?
let me introduce
oh, bob, let me introduce rosie webb, our new marketing manager.
allow me to introduce[formal]
please allow me to introduce myself. i’m john fetty, the head of business development.

children.name: this is
children.definition: say this when you are introducing sb to a person they have never met before: đây là
examples: ‘sam, this is julia - she’s in college with me.’ ‘hi, julia, nice to meet you!’
‘mom, dad, this is my friend matt.’ ‘hello, matt, we’ve heard a lot about you.’

children.name: not get along b1
children.definition: not get along/not get on  if people do not get along or do not get on, they have a bad relationship and they often argue and disagree with each other: không hòa hợp với nhau
examples: barney and i just don’t get along.
not get along with
troy doesn’t get along with the coach, so he’s thinking of quitting the team.
she never got on with her father and she hates her new stepmother.

children.name: have a falling-out x
children.definition: have a falling-out/fall out  if friends or relatives have a falling-out or they fall out, they have an argument and stop being friendly with each other: bất hòa, xích mích
examples: they fell out last year, and they won’t even speak to each other now.
the three children had an enormous falling-out over their inheritance when their father died.
have a falling-out with
he’s fallen out with his girlfriend again.
daly had a falling-out with her boss, which led to her being fired.

children.name: incompatible x
children.definition: incompatible people who are incompatible cannot have a good relationship with each other because they are completely different in their characters, interests etc: xung khắc, kỵ nhau
examples: we’re completely incompatible - she’s a neat freak, and i hate to clean.
they’ve always seemed so incompatible - no wonder they’re getting a divorce.

children.name: drive a wedge between x
children.definition: drive a wedge between sb if sth drives a wedge between two people or groups, it has a bad effect on their relationship: chia rẽ
examples: the war had driven a wedge between the president and his liberal supporters.
romley’s lawsuit drove the wedge even farther between the two former friends.

children.name: get to know b1
children.definition: get to know to start to become friends with sb by spending a lot of time with them and talking to them: làm quen
examples: the volunteers had a lot of trouble getting to know the local people.
being stuck on a small boat, you get to know someone pretty well.
steve’s alright once you get to know him.

children.name: get acquainted x
children.definition: get acquainted to start to know sb who you have only just met: làm quen
examples: i’ll leave you two alone so you can get acquainted.
get acquainted with
i had no problems getting acquainted with the girls, but the guys were a little harder.
get better acquainted
maybe we should invite sam round for dinner so we can get better acquainted.

children.name: meet a1
children.definition: meet to meet sb you have not met before: gặp mặt, gặp gỡ
examples: have you ever met his wife?
i was 15 years old when i met andrew.
dave, meet my brother tom.
‘how did you two meet?’ ‘we were on the same exchange program in madrid.’
i’d like you all to meet my girlfriend, claudia.
where did you meet michael?
carol and i first met at university.
branford took us to meet a few of his colleagues.
first meet
where did you first meet dr steiner?
janet and pete first met at a mutual friend’s cocktail party.
nice/ pleased/ glad to meet you[use this to politely say "hello" to someone you have just met]
‘hello, my name is alan.’ ‘hi, alan. my name’s cindy. nice to meet you.’
‘doug, i’d like you to meet my mother.’ ‘oh, pleased to meet you, mrs haggerty.’

children.name: make sb’s acquaintance x
children.definition: make sb’s acquaintance  to meet sb for the first time: gặp ai đó (trang trọng)
examples: i’m pleased to make your acquaintance.
after seeing the way mr. wyatt behaved at the party, i had little desire to make his acquaintance.

children.name: make friends a1
children.definition: make friends to start to be sb’s friend, especially when you have to make an effort to do this: kết bạn
examples: her family moved a lot, and it wasn’t always easy to make friends.
make friends with
the children soon made friends with the kids next door.

children.name: become friends a1
children.definition: become friends if two people become friends, they begin to be friends: trở thành bạn bè
examples: they met at an art class and became friends.
i’d known him for years, but we really didn’t become friends until high school.

children.name: hit it off b2
children.definition: hit it off informal if two people hit it off, they immediately become friends when they meet for the first time: tâm đầu ý hợp
examples: i knew you and mark would hit it off.
the two men ended up in the same business law class and hit it off immediately.
i didn't really hit it offwithhis friends.

children.name: click c2
children.definition: click informal if two people click, they like each other immediately when they first meet, because they have the same ideas or opinions, or laugh at the same things: tâm đầu ý hợp
examples: we just clicked, and we’ve been friends ever since.
click with
i never really clicked with my boss, and it made work a little more difficult.

children.name: strike up a friendship x
children.definition: strike up a friendship to make friends with sb very quickly, especially if you do it intentionally: bắt đầu tình bạn
examples: the two women struck up a friendship when they met on holiday.
we met for the first time at a business conference, and we immediately struck up afriendship which has lasted for years.

children.name: befriend x
children.definition: befriend to be friendly to sb who needs help, for example sb with financial or emotional problems: là bạn tốt của
examples: his parents befriended some american soldiers who served in wales during world war ii.
it’s fairly unusual for high school seniors to befriend freshmen.

children.name: fall in with x
children.definition: fall in with/get in with  to begin to be friends with a group of people, especially people that other people do not approve of: kết thân với (nhóm người không được ưa chuộng lắm)
examples: he’s fallen in with a group of boys i don’t like very much.
she used her husband’s money and family to get in with a group of hollywood’s social elite.

children.name: be friends a1
children.definition: be friends if two people are friends, they like each other and they enjoy doing things together: là bạn của nhau
examples: bill and i used to be good friends, but we don’t see each other much now.
be friends with
i’ve been friends with andrea for about 10 years.

children.name: get along b1
children.definition: get along/get on   if two or more people get along or get on, they find it easy to talk and agree with each other, and so they feel relaxed when they spend time together: thân thiết
examples: i used to argue a lot with my parents, but now we get along fine.
get along with
julie’s nice, but i don’t really get on with her brother.
he’s a nice boy - very easy to get along with.

children.name: be friendly with a2
children.definition: be friendly with to have a good relationship with sb, even though you may not spend a lot of time together: thân thiết với
examples: her family became very friendly with their neighbors, the mayers.
i used to be very friendly with a girl from boston.

children.name: have a good relationship b1
children.definition: have a good relationship when two people or groups are friendly towards each other and work well together: có mối quan hệ tốt
examples: my boss and i have a very good relationship.
have a good relationship with
it’s important that the school have a good relationship with the students’ parents.
the president has a good working relationship with this congress.

children.name: get along b1
children.definition: get along/geton  if two or more people get along or get on, they have a friendly relationship with each other: hòa hợp với nhau
examples: i don’t understand why you two girls don’t get along.
get along with
he’s very easy to get along with.
martin was chosen because he is a good administrator who gets along with everyone.
get along well
we all get on really well, so we’re going to share a flat next year.
get along like a house on fire[extremely well] thân thiết vô cùng
i wasn’t sure whether david and ann would like each other, but they got on like a house on fire.

children.name: be on good terms c2
children.definition: be on good, friendly, etc. terms if people are on good terms, they have a polite relationship and they can work well together, but they are not close friends: giao thiệp tốt, quan hệ tốt, giao hảo tốt
examples: they divorced several years ago, but they’re still on good terms.
my ex-wife and i are still on friendly terms.
be on good terms with
we’re on good terms with all our neighbours except the couple upstairs.
taylor has managed to remain on good terms with his former employers.
are you on good terms with your boss?

children.name: close a2
children.definition: close/kləʊs/  if two or more people are close, they like each other very much, and can talk to each other about their feelings, their problems etc:thân thiết
examples: ▪ dad and i have always been very close.
close to:thân thiết với
▪ she was never very close to her stepmother.
close friend: bạnthân thiết
▪ it turns out that julie is a close friend of my cousin kelly.
closeadjectiverelationshipthân; thân thiết
describes people who know each other very well and like each other a lot, or who see and talk to each other a lot
_mira is one of my closestfriends.
_her relationship isn't good with her father, but she's very closetoher mother.
_my brother and i have become much closer over the years.

children.name: spend time with friends or people
mix b2
children.definition: mix to meet, talk, and spend time with other people, especially people you do not know very well: hoà nhập, giao thiệp
examples: she mixes very well - perhaps that's why she's so popular.
mix with
charlie doesn’t mix well with the other children.
i suppose you mixwitha wide variety of people in your job.

children.name: socialize b2
children.definition: socialize  to spend the time when you are not working with friends or with other people in order to enjoy yourself : xã giao, giao thiệp
examples: i hope adrian's actually doing some work at college -he seems to spend all his time socializing!
socialize with
people don’t socialize with their neighbours as much as they used to.
i tend not to socializewithmy colleagues.

children.name: hang out b1
children.definition: hang out  to spend a lot of time in a particular place or with particular people : đi chơi, tụ tập
examples: you still hang outatthe pool hall?
hang out with
i don’t really know who she hangs out with.
where do the youngsters hang out?
i've been hanging out backstagewiththe band.

children.name: mingle c1
children.definition: mingle to move around and talk to other people at a social event :hoà mình với
examples: mingle with
you've been talking to roger all evening - you really ought to be minglingwiththe other guests.
she was eager to mingle with the other guests.

children.name: get out c1
children.definition: get out to go out to different places and socialize : ra ngoài, chơi bời, xã giao
examples: we don't get out much since we had the children.
